maml:description.maml:para: Gets the network adapters on the local computer or a remote one
Gets the network adapters on the local computer or a remote one. No filter is applied to the list other than optionally selecting a NIC by name
The name of a network adapter to get. Wildcards are supported; because the adapters are fetched using WMI the WildCard is %, * will be converted to %.
The name of the server where command should be run using WMI remoting. . or localhost can be used for the local computer.
The name of a network adapter to get. Wildcards are supported; because the adapters are fetched using WMI the WildCard is %, * will be converted to %.
The name of the server where command should be run using WMI remoting. . or localhost can be used for the local computer.
Shows a list to allow the user to select an IP-Enabled NIC
If more than one Network adapter is enabled for IP, a list is show and the adapter selected by the user is returned. If there is only one is enabled for IP it is returned.
The name of the server where command should be run using WMI remoting. . or localhost can be used for the local computer.
The name of the server where command should be run using WMI remoting. . or localhost can be used for the local computer.
Returns objects with similar information to the familiar "IPconfig" command
The command will accept one or more Network adapters as a parameter, and will return Win32_NetworkAdapterConfiguration WMI Objects. It can take parameters to produce formatted output.

Either a WMI object representing a Network-Adapter, a string object containing a Network-Adapter name (which may contain wildcards) or an array of such objects. This can be passed via the pipeline. If nothing is passed all Adapters are queried.
The name of the server where command should be run using WMI remoting. . or localhost can be used for the local computer.
A list of property names to be used to format the output as a table. The names can include the Property Set names, "DHCP", "DNS", "IP", "PSStatus" and "WINS"

A list of property names to be used to format the output as a list. The names can include the Property Set names, "DHCP", "DNS", "IP", "PSStatus" and "WINS" and a psuedo-Property Set "All" If both table and list are specified, a list is displayed.
A short form for -List *

Either a WMI object representing a Network-Adapter, a string object containing a Network-Adapter name (which may contain wildcards) or an array of such objects. This can be passed via the pipeline. If nothing is passed all Adapters are queried.
The name of the server where command should be run using WMI remoting. . or localhost can be used for the local computer.
A list of property names to be used to format the output as a table. The names can include the Property Set names, "DHCP", "DNS", "IP", "PSStatus" and "WINS"

A list of property names to be used to format the output as a list. The names can include the Property Set names, "DHCP", "DNS", "IP", "PSStatus" and "WINS" and a psuedo-Property Set "All" If both table and list are specified, a list is displayed.
A short form for -List *
Network adapters can be piped into Get-IpConfig

dev:remarks.maml:para: Will Return information about IP-Enabled adapters stored in $nics . If not piped into another command or stored in a variable,this will be formatted following Powershell's Defaults

Will get the configuration data for all network adapters with names which start "Intel". This will be output as a table using the property named "IP"; in fact "IP" is the name of a Property-Set which will expanded by the Format-Table cmdlet.

Will return information about all IPEnabled adapters, in a list format. "All" is handled specially. * may be used to mean "Every Property". Property names and Property-Set names can be used as in the Table Example.

maml:description.maml:para: Sets the IP Configuration for a network adapter
The command will accept Network adapters as a parameter, and set their IPv4 or IpV6 address, subnet, gateway, WINS and DNS servers and enabled DHCP.

Either a WMI object representing a Network-Adapter, a string object containing a Network-Adapter name. A name may contain wildcards but must resolve to one adapter. This can be passed via the pipeline.
An array of strings containing IPv4 and/or IPv6 address
An array of strings containing the Subnet mask(s) the corresponding to each IP address. For IPv4 it is dotted decimal notation. For IPv6 it is number of bits.

An array of strings containing the default gateway(s) to be used. Note that although windows supports setting different metrics for routes, the function does not. This can be done using route.exe if required
A single string containing the address of the Primary WINS server in dotted decimal notation.
A single string containing the address of the Secondary WINS server in dotted decimal notation
An array of strings containing the IPv4 or IPv6 addresses of DNS Servers in order of preference
The name of the server where command should be run using WMI remoting. . or localhost can be used for the local computer.
If specified the networks are configured to use DHCP for both IPV4 and IPV6

Either a WMI object representing a Network-Adapter, a string object containing a Network-Adapter name. A name may contain wildcards but must resolve to one adapter. This can be passed via the pipeline.
An array of strings containing IPv4 and/or IPv6 address
An array of strings containing the Subnet mask(s) the corresponding to each IP address. For IPv4 it is dotted decimal notation. For IPv6 it is number of bits.

An array of strings containing the default gateway(s) to be used. Note that although windows supports setting different metrics for routes, the function does not. This can be done using route.exe if required
A single string containing the address of the Primary WINS server in dotted decimal notation.
A single string containing the address of the Secondary WINS server in dotted decimal notation
An array of strings containing the IPv4 or IPv6 addresses of DNS Servers in order of preference
The name of the server where command should be run using WMI remoting. . or localhost can be used for the local computer.
If specified the networks are configured to use DHCP for both IPV4 and IPV6
Network Adapters can be piped into Set-IpConfig
Performs the equivalent of Ipconfig /renew
Gets a new IP address from a DHCP Servre

Either a WMI object representing a Network-Adapter, a string object containing a Network-Adapter name (which may contain wildcards) or an array of such objects. This can be passed via the pipeline. If nothing is passed all Adapters are queried.

Either a WMI object representing a Network-Adapter, a string object containing a Network-Adapter name (which may contain wildcards) or an array of such objects. This can be passed via the pipeline. If nothing is passed all Adapters are queried.
Network Adapters can be piped into New-IpConfig
Performs the equivalent of Ipconfig /release
Release an IP address previously obtained from a DHCP Servre

Either a WMI object representing a Network-Adapter, a string object containing a Network-Adapter name (which may contain wildcards) or an array of such objects. This can be passed via the pipeline. If nothing is passed all Adapters are queried.

Either a WMI object representing a Network-Adapter, a string object containing a Network-Adapter name (which may contain wildcards) or an array of such objects. This can be passed via the pipeline. If nothing is passed all Adapters are queried.
Network Adapters can be piped into Remove-IpConfig
